She misses the social interaction with colleagues, but she loves being responsible for her own work.
Paul Drinkwater used to work in finance, but he became a masseur. He was tired of the fast-paced world of finance and wanted to do something more rewarding. He took courses in massage and started working part-time at a health center. He's happy with his decision and feels in control of his life.

Dave and Norm Lagasse are two brothers who have turned their childhood game into a successful business. They are sitting in their home in Santa Fe, New Mexico, playing the game of pichenotte. Their grandfather, Lucien Rajotte, brought the game to the USA from Quebec, Canada. The family loved playing the game on weekends and holidays. When they moved to New Mexico, they continued to play with the board their grandfather made from old wooden crates.
One day, Dave decided to make a new board because the old one was broken. A relative and a friend wanted one, and soon more people were asking for the game. The brothers took one of Dave's new boards to a sports bar and people were surprised by how much fun it was. They started asking about the game's origins, and Dave researched and found that it came from India, was adapted in Britain, and then brought to Canada by British people.
Pichenotte is a game of skill that can be played with two to four people. Each player has 12 pieces, or pucks, and tries to flick them onto a board with a wheel-like shape. The game is usually played for two minutes, and the player with the most points wins. The Lagasses started selling the boards at markets and craft fairs, and soon people were buying them. They even started holding championships and creating a trophy called the Lord Pichenotte Cup.
The brothers decided to start making the boards full-time and set up a workshop in their garage. They have made over 450 boards so far, which are made of birchwood and mahogany and are very durable. They sell the boards on their website for $595 each. While they don't have professional players or TV coverage yet, they hope that their business will grow and they will be able to buy a luxury car. For now, they are happy to play the game they love and make a living from it.

Welcome to the Model Village! This place used to be a piece of waste ground with brambles. But one man, Colin Sims, and his wife worked hard to turn it into this beautiful village. They moved a lot of soil and clay to create the landscape you see today. It was a big job that required a lot of hard work, but it was worth it.
To make the village look like a real place, they planted hundreds of trees and shrubs. They had to choose plants that could survive in a salty, windy area near the sea. Some plants came from local garden centers, while others came from as far away as Canada and New Zealand.
Colin Sims made all the models himself over nine years. He used different materials like stone, concrete, and plastic to make them last. He had to learn how to make them strong and durable, but he became an expert.
You'll notice that everything is on a small scale and looks very detailed. This took a lot of patience and special techniques. The Model Village is very popular and is known for its high-quality work.
You can see many different buildings, including a castle, a church, a zoo, and a mini golf course. Please stay on the paths and don't touch the models. You can take photos from the paths, but not from close up. Dogs are welcome on a short lead.
We hope you enjoy your visit and would love to hear your comments. We're always planning new models and would like to know what you think. If you have any suggestions or ideas, please let us know!

British newspapers often publish pictures that invade people's privacy and break their own rules. Celebrities usually don't pose for photographers, but sometimes they do. However, most people in the public eye suffer when their private moments are published on the front page. Few people complain to the Press Complaints Commission (PCC), which was set up to deal with these issues. These pictures are rarely in the public interest. Do pictures of famous people help solve crimes? How did a famous actress's hotel room photo protect public health and safety? The actress has complained about paparazzi pictures before, but this time she didn't. The PCC should have looked into it.
The PCC should also investigate a recent story about a pop star's private life. The pop star didn't complain either. Shouldn't the PCC take the initiative? It seems like a good idea, but there are some problems. The PCC would have to decide when to investigate and how to do it. It would also have to deal with celebrities who might be upset if their stories weren't published. The PCC would have to monitor all British newspapers, which is a big task. Some people might not want an investigation because they're embarrassed. Others might be worried that a worse story would come out if they complained.
A British comedian was also a victim of the press. He and his wife were secretly photographed on their honeymoon, and later, on a family holiday. He didn't complain because he was afraid the newspaper would run the pictures again with a new story about his anger. People are afraid to challenge the tabloids because they think they'll be targeted again. It's hard to find a solution to this problem.

When you have been in your first job for a while, you might think about moving to a new job. This is a big decision, and you should think carefully about what you want to do. You might want to stay in the same field, take on more responsibility, or try something new.
When choosing a new job, think about your long-term goals. Do you want to specialize in a particular area or move to a different field? You should choose a job that will help you grow and develop as a professional.
It's also a good idea to think about your future. You might want to travel or take a break before moving to a new job. This can be a good way to gain new experiences and skills.
Juliette Davidson, for example, worked for three solicitors after leaving college. She liked her first job, but it didn't offer much opportunity for advancement. So, she took a year off to travel and then found a new job as a Personal Assistant to a Chief Executive. In two and a half years, she has become more confident and her job has changed. She now does more important tasks, like managing correspondence and budgets, and works on special projects.
When choosing a new job, remember to think about your long-term goals and what you want to achieve. Choose a job that will help you grow and develop as a professional, and don't be afraid to take a break or try something new.

'What's the secret to being confident? Many people think confident people are born that way, but most will tell you it's a skill they've learned. Five people share their stories of how they gained confidence.
A) Jenny was shy when she left school, but she surprised herself by doing well at her daughter's school. She then took a university course and became more outgoing.
B) Michaela had to take over her family business when her father got ill. At first, she was scared and became too aggressive. But she learned that confidence comes from believing in yourself.
C) Lisa seems confident, but she's actually very nervous. She's learned to hide her fears by focusing on being friendly and calm. She also believes that doing things that scare you can help you build confidence.
D) Barbara's confidence comes from enjoying her work and learning from her mistakes. She works hard and doesn't let others' opinions affect her. She also thinks it's important to like yourself and set achievable goals.
E) Kim used to be too scared to speak up in meetings, but she eventually found her voice. She tells herself that everyone is nervous when speaking in public and reminds herself that "nothing is impossible". She also writes down notes to help her feel more confident.'

I visited a kite-flying festival in Malaysia with a friend named Adnan. He gave me a kite as a gift because the string had broken. I was surprised and asked him why. He said it's a tradition in Malaysia - if the string breaks, the finder gets to keep the kite. He showed me his many kites, all the same size and made of special paper and bamboo.
We sat under some trees and looked out at the festival. There were 10 platforms where people held up their kites, and many people waiting to let their kites fly. When the whistle blew, the kites went up in the air like rockets. There were over 500 people competing, and they had to make four different kites each. Adnan told me that making kites is not easy, but flying them is not so hard.
Adnan invited me to visit him at his home, and I accepted. He showed me around and we had tea and snacks. He said I could come back the next day to help him make a new kite, but I didn't have time. Instead, I drove to a nearby town and then got lost in the forest. I met a man named Baba who had a tent and some huts, and I decided to stay there. The night was dark and noisy, but I was too tired to worry about the insects. The next morning, I woke up to a beautiful view of the mountains. It rained later, and I got wet, but I was relieved to find my car was still there at the bottom of the track.
When I got back to the city, everyone was friendly and curious. They asked me where I was from and how old I was, but it was all friendly. I remember my trip to Kelantan more for the kind people than the kites.

Do you like shopping? There are different types of shoppers. Let's see which one you are.
A. Melanie, a dancer, is an addicted shopper. She loves buying things and doesn't feel bad about spending money.
B. Brenda, an office manager, is a reluctant shopper. She doesn't like shopping and only goes when she has to. She usually buys things for her family, not for herself.
C. Juliet, a personnel manager, only buys essentials. She doesn't like shopping and tries to get in and out quickly.
D. Anita, a TV producer, likes to shop, but she knows what she wants and doesn't waste time.
E. Lizzie, a secretary, doesn't enjoy shopping at all. She finds it stressful and usually buys clothes that are given to her.
F. Lisa, an actress, is a happy shopper. She likes going to the shops with her friends and buying things that catch her eye.
G. Suki, an art gallery assistant, is a careful shopper. She likes to shop, but she doesn't buy much and tries not to spend too much money.
H. Ann-Marie, a nursery worker, loves shopping, but only on certain days. She is a careful shopper and likes to look for bargains.
I. Linda, a restaurant manager, is an unwilling shopper. She only goes shopping when she has to and doesn't like trying on clothes.
These are just a few examples of different types of shoppers. Which one are you?
